Title.evidence: Effects of ESRT on Stress and Cognitive Function in PGY-1 Trainees: A Randomised Controlled Trial

Trial_Design.evidence: Two small single-institution randomised clinical trials were conducted.

Participants.evidence: Participants included first-year surgical (ESRT-1, n = 44) and mixed specialty (ESRT-2, n = 45) residents.

Intervention.evidence: ESRT-1 consisted of 8 weekly 2-hour classes, while ESRT-2 comprised 6 weekly 90-minute classes.

Objective.evidence: This study investigates the impact of an iteratively adapted MBI, ESRT, on perceived stress, executive cognitive function, psychosocial well-being, and pro-inflammatory gene expression in surgical and mixed specialty PGY-1 trainees.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was perceived stress, measured pre- and post-intervention and at follow-up.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was achieved using a computer-generated sequence, with allocation concealment.

Blinding.evidence: Outcome assessors were blinded to group assignments.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Participants included first-year surgical (ESRT-1, n = 44) and mixed specialty (ESRT-2, n = 45) residents.

Result_Outcome.evidence: ESRT did not significantly impact perceived stress. However, ESRT-1 participants exhibited higher executive function and mindfulness scores, while ESRT-2 participants showed reduced emotional exhaustion and depersonalization scores at follow-up.

Harms.evidence: No adverse events were reported in either group.
